title: British Amazon account is hacked by US-based fraudster
text:
A This is Money reader was charged over £300 by Amazon for a TV she didn't order after a fraudster illegally accessed her account.

Gillian Weston, a British pensioner, got home to find a Samsung television waiting for her in her porch earlier this month and, although the item was delivered by UPS, Gillian says she never signed for it.

Initially confused, she looked online and found that £311.95 had been taken out of her bank account by Amazon.

After doing some digging she found out that the purchase was made on Amazon.com, the American version of the online retail giant, but was sent to her at her UK address.

Gillian was shocked to find out that over £300 had been taken from her account (stock image)

The hacker waited for confirmation of the item being shipped and dispatched before requesting a return and replacement of the same product to be shipped to a US address under a different name.

She said: 'I was the subject of quite a sophisticated fraud because for it to be a success was dependent on Amazon's lax policies for the return and replacement of goods.'

Gillian can't say for sure how the hacker managed to access her account.

Amazon has suggested it could have been through a phishing email, designed to look like a genuine Amazon email, where she clicked on the link and gave her details as she thought it was genuine correspondence from the site.

However, she believes her details could also have been obtained by criminals in any of the many data breaches that have occurred over the past few years.

After discovering the name and address where the scammer requested the replacement TV be sent, Gillian searched the details on the internet, finding many comments from other people who had suffered similar experiences to her.

They'd all fallen victim to the same scam by the same person.

She also found that her email account associated with Amazon had been modified to include filters that would prevent her from seeing emails from Amazon, DHL, FedEx, UPS and any email with the word return - but no emails were being forwarded to any other address.

Gillian immediately contacted Amazon for help after discovering the loss of money and also reported the incident to both Action Fraud and Trading Standards.

After she asked for an explanation, Amazon confirmed that her account was accessed by an unauthorised party but she claims it did not initially provide her with much help for returning the television.

Hacked: Gillian had a TV delivered to her house - even though she hadn't ordered one

In fact, she said Amazon UK told her to keep the television – even though she did not want it and did not want to pay for it.

She said: 'I have had so much conflicting advice from Amazon customer service - "keep the item, return the item at your expense and we will refund the shipping".'

Since the incident, she has had four Amazon account alerts and lock downs including one in Portuguese from Amazon Brazil and four chargeback alerts, which are activated when a customer contacts their bank or credit card company to dispute the charge for an order that they placed or - in this case - didn't place.

Luckily, after contacting her bank, it was sympathetic and returned the funds to her account – recognising that it looked like a fraudulent transaction.

As soon as Amazon received the chargeback notice from Gillian's bank, it locked her account and removed the orders from the history of the account.

Whilst Gillian didn't have much joy with Amazon initially, after This is Money contacted the site about the incident, it provided her with a prepaid label to return the television to Amazon USA via UPS as well as a £100 gift card as a gesture of goodwill.

An Amazon spokesperson said: 'From time to time, customers may receive e-mails appearing to come from Amazon, which are actually false emails, sometimes called "spoof emails" or "phishing emails".

'These can look similar to real Amazon emails but often direct the recipient to a false website where they might be asked to provide account information such as their e-mail address and password combination.

'The best way to ensure that you do not respond to a false or phishing email is to always go directly to your account on Amazon to review or make any changes to your orders or your account.

'We would ask any customer who believes that they have received a false or phishing email to alert us via our stop-spoofing@amazon.com email address.'

Whilst Amazon suggests it could have been a phishing email that allowed hackers access, Gillian has been given no concrete information about how this hack was made possible and what possible repercussions there may have been for the hacker.

Gillian added: 'This whole affair has left me constantly checking my account.'

What to do if your Amazon account has been hacked

Have you been scammed? Contact This is Money to let us and know and we'll help you get your money back if we can. Email grace.gausden@thisismoney.co.uk

If you have had your Amazon account hacked, one of the first things you should do is contact the site on 0800 279 7234 to report it.

Another step you should take is to change your password - preferably making it something completely different.

Make sure to report the incident to your bank so they are aware of any fraudulent transactions but say that you wish to dispute a transaction as opposed to immediately reporting it as fraud.

Where fraud is alleged, banks can launch investigations which means it may take longer for victims to get their money back.

If you paid by debit card, ask the bank to take back the money using chargeback rules. There is a limited time frame with chargeback claims so ensure you make them within 120 days of the payments being made.

If you paid by credit card, ask for a refund under Section 75 of the Consumer Credit Act.

Adam French, Which? consumer rights expert, said: 'Amazon suggests this could have been a phishing scam - an example of one of the increasingly sophisticated tactics fraudsters are using to steal sensitive information such as logins and card details for a variety of purposes, including to make fraudulent purchases online.

'If you are a victim of this type of scam, you should change your login details immediately and contact the retailer to dispute this transaction and request a refund.

'If the retailer doesn't help, contact your bank or credit card provider to try and get your money back.'
description: Gillian Weston, a retired British pensioner, found a Samsung television waiting for her in her porch earlier this month. She looked online and found that £311.95 had been taken out of her account.
